column4: Hi, I've got some technical questions regarding Wubi/Lubi, is there a more appropriate channel I can talk in than here?

Okay so basically I'd like to use the Wubi bootloader system to boot another OS, but it appears that Wubi uses a loop-mounted ISO image to boot, am I correct? I'd need to boot from a hard disk image, is this possible?
Wubi does boot a raw hard disk image located in C:\ubuntu\disks\root.disk
Ah, I presume that's MBR partitioned disk? Would a GPT image work?
I don't think so...
Is there somewhere with technical documentation on how Wubi works? If it doesn't support booting GPT, I'd like to add that functionality.
wubi-installer.org is the place for everything related to it
Is it definitely a disk image and not just a partition image? I keep seeing reference to an ext2 disk image, which would suggest it's a partition rather than a full disk
It's a disk with one partition, and it's ext3 rather than ext2 from what I'm aware. Not so sure tho, I hate wubi (and neither I use Ubuntu, really)
How exactly is the NTFS partition accessed to use the disk image stored there?
Trough the Windows bootloader (it chainloads GRUB)
No magic going on in the initrd then?
Or special options required in the kernel
Nah
Does the root need to be specified by uuid or is there some way of specifying a partition index?
Usually I'd specify like sdx3 but given it's a loop device loop0 I'm not sure how this works
errrr for the kernel you can use the uuid, the label or plain /dev/sd*, same goes to fstab
Oh loop0? Well I beleive you might be able to use /dev/loop0 but...
Just trying to boot what was USB stick image, root would usually be sdb3
you sure root.disk is a disk image? when booted to ubuntu, / is mounted to /dev/loop0, can't see any way of booting from a specific partition on the disk
I am not, as stated before, I haven't used WUBI or Ubuntu for ages. That's how it used to be at least...
